title: Jeremiah Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who did the LORD say stood before Him but His mind could not be toward the people?
options: Moses and Samuel
David and Solomon
Elijah and Elisha
Abraham and Isaac
questions.correctAnswer: Moses and Samuel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:1 states that though Moses and Samuel stood before the LORD, His mind could not be toward the people.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:2, what will happen to those who are for death?
options: They shall be taken to death
They shall be healed
They shall be forgiven
They shall be protected
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be taken to death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:2 says that such as are for death shall go to death.

questions.question: How many kinds of judgment did the LORD say He will appoint over them?
options: Four
Three
Five
Two
questions.correctAnswer: Four
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:3 states that the LORD will appoint four kinds: the sword, dogs, fowls of heaven, and beasts of the earth.

questions.question: Because of whose actions in Jerusalem will God cause the people to be removed into all kingdoms of the earth?
options: Manasseh the son of Hezekiah
David the son of Jesse
Solomon the son of David
Josiah the son of Amon
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh the son of Hezekiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:4 specifies that the removal is because of Manasseh, son of Hezekiah king of Judah, for what he did in Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 15:5 asks who will have pity upon Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:5 asks who shall have pity upon Jerusalem.

questions.question: What has Jerusalem done that caused the LORD to say He will stretch out His hand against them?
options: Forsaken the LORD and gone backward
Built many idols
Fought against their neighbors
Sinned in secret
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaken the LORD and gone backward
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:6 says Jerusalem has forsaken the LORD and gone backward, so He will stretch out His hand to destroy them.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:7, what will the LORD do to His people because they do not return from their ways?
options: Bereave them of children and destroy them
Bless them with many children
Give them abundant harvests
Protect them from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Bereave them of children and destroy them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:7 states that the LORD will bereave them of children and destroy His people since they do not return from their ways.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Their widows are increased to me above the ______ of the seas.'
options: sand
waves
mountains
stars
questions.correctAnswer: sand
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:8 says 'Their widows are increased to me above the sand of the seas.'

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:10, how does Jeremiah describe himself?
options: A man of strife and contention
A man of peace and love
A man of wealth and honor
A man of silence and solitude
questions.correctAnswer: A man of strife and contention
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:10 says Jeremiah laments being a man of strife and contention to the whole earth.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 15:11 says the LORD will cause the enemy to treat the remnant well in times of affliction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:11 states that it shall be well with the remnant and the enemy will entreat them well in affliction.

questions.question: What will happen to the treasures and substance according to Jeremiah 15:13?
options: They will be given to spoil without price
They will be stored safely
They will be multiplied
They will be hidden underground
questions.correctAnswer: They will be given to spoil without price
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:13 says treasures and substance will be given to spoil without price for all sins.

questions.question: Where will the LORD cause the people to pass with their enemies?
options: Into a land which they know not
Back to their own land
Into a land of milk and honey
Into a desert wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Into a land which they know not
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:14 states the people will pass with their enemies into a land unknown to them.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 15:16 says Jeremiah ate the words of the LORD and they brought him joy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:16 describes Jeremiah eating the words of the LORD and feeling joy and rejoicing.

questions.question: What reason does Jeremiah give for sitting alone and not rejoicing in Jeremiah 15:17?
options: Because of the LORD's hand filling him with indignation
Because he was sick
Because he was traveling
Because he was celebrating alone
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the LORD's hand filling him with indignation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:17 says he sat alone because the LORD's hand filled him with indignation.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:20, what will the LORD make Jeremiah to this people?
options: A fenced brazen wall
A mighty king
A humble servant
A wise teacher
questions.correctAnswer: A fenced brazen wall
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:20 states the LORD will make Jeremiah a fenced brazen wall to the people.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of rejection and loneliness because of their faith. Based on Jeremiah 15, what biblical truth would you share about God's presence in trials?
options: God will be with you to save and deliver you.
You are abandoned and must rely on yourself.
God has forgotten you in your suffering.
You must endure alone without help.
questions.correctAnswer: God will be with you to save and deliver you.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:20-21 assures us that God will be a 'fenced brasen wall' protecting us and that He is with us to save and deliver us, even when others fight against us.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 15 teach us about the importance of repentance and obedience in our relationship with God?
options: If you return, God will restore you and use you as His mouthpiece.
God will ignore your repentance and punish you anyway.
Repentance is unnecessary for God's blessings.
Obedience does not affect God's plans for you.
questions.correctAnswer: If you return, God will restore you and use you as His mouthpiece.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:19 explains that if we return to God, He will bring us back and make us like His mouth, emphasizing the blessing of repentance and obedience.

questions.question: A church member feels overwhelmed by persecution for their faith and questions God's justice. What encouragement does Jeremiah 15 offer regarding suffering for God's sake?
options: God knows your suffering and will remember you.
Suffering means God has abandoned you.
You should stop following God to avoid pain.
Persecution is a sign of failure.
questions.correctAnswer: God knows your suffering and will remember you.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:15 shows Jeremiah asking God to remember him and not to take him away despite suffering for God's sake, illustrating God's awareness and care.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 15 teach about trusting God's discipline even when it causes pain?
options: God's discipline is a sign of His involvement and love.
Pain means God has rejected you.
Discipline is useless and should be avoided.
God will never allow hardship for His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God's discipline is a sign of His involvement and love.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:17-18 depicts Jeremiah's pain but also his recognition that God’s hand is upon him, teaching that suffering can be part of God’s loving discipline.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 15 encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in their dealings despite opposition?
options: Jeremiah had not lent or borrowed with usury yet was cursed, showing integrity amidst trials.
It is acceptable to compromise honesty to avoid curses.
One should avoid all difficulties by being dishonest.
Integrity guarantees a life free from hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Jeremiah had not lent or borrowed with usury yet was cursed, showing integrity amidst trials.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:10 highlights Jeremiah’s honest dealings and the undeserved cursing he faced, teaching believers to maintain integrity even when misunderstood.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to join worldly mockers to fit in. According to Jeremiah 15, what counsel would you give about fellowship and standing firm in faith?
options: Do not join the assembly of mockers; stand alone if necessary.
Joining mockers is acceptable to avoid loneliness.
Faith requires blending in with everyone.
Mocking believers is harmless and can be ignored.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not join the assembly of mockers; stand alone if necessary.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:17 shows Jeremiah choosing not to join mockers and instead sitting alone because of God’s hand upon him, encouraging believers to remain faithful even if isolated.

questions.question: In what way does Jeremiah 15 teach about God's justice and consequences for sin?
options: God will bring destruction and remove the people due to their sins.
Sin has no consequences before God.
God always overlooks sin to show mercy.
Sin leads to immediate forgiveness without repentance.
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring destruction and remove the people due to their sins.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:3-4 and 13 describe God's appointed instruments of judgment and the removal of the people because of their sins, showing the reality of divine justice.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 15 teaches that God’s anger can lead to exile and suffering for His people as a consequence of their disobedience.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:14 states that God will make the people pass with their enemies into an unknown land because of His anger, confirming that exile and suffering are consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 15 encourages believers to despair because God will not save them from their enemies.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:21 promises deliverance from the hand of the wicked, assuring believers that God will save and redeem them despite opposition.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah describes himself as a man of _____ and contention to the whole earth, yet he maintains his integrity.
options: strife
peace
joy
faith
questions.correctAnswer: strife
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:10 states, 'Woe is me, my mother, that thou hast borne me a man of strife and a man of contention to the whole earth,' showing his difficult role but steadfastness.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 15 instruct believers about finding joy and strength in God's Word during hardship?
options: God’s words are the joy and rejoicing of the heart.
The Word of God is burdensome and discouraging.
Faith should be based on feelings, not God’s Word.
God’s Word is irrelevant in times of trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s words are the joy and rejoicing of the heart.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:16 shows Jeremiah eating God's words and finding joy and rejoicing in them, teaching believers to find strength in Scripture.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because of ongoing wounds and pain. According to Jeremiah 15, how should one view persistent suffering?
options: Suffering may feel incurable but God’s presence remains.
Persistent pain means God has rejected you.
You should give up faith because of pain.
Suffering is a sign of God’s abandonment.
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering may feel incurable but God’s presence remains.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:18 expresses Jeremiah’s pain yet questions God’s faithfulness, prompting believers to trust God even when healing feels distant.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 15 reveal about the role of prayer and personal devotion in facing persecution?
options: Prayer is a means to ask God for remembrance and justice.
Prayer is useless in persecution.
Personal devotion should be abandoned when facing trials.
God does not hear prayers of the persecuted.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is a means to ask God for remembrance and justice.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:15 shows Jeremiah praying for God to remember him and take vengeance on persecutors, encouraging believers to seek God in prayer.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 15 teach about God’s use of human leaders and circumstances to carry out His will?
options: God appoints swords, dogs, birds, and beasts to execute judgment.
God ignores human affairs and leaders.
God’s will is unrelated to earthly events.
Human leaders act independently of God’s plan.
questions.correctAnswer: God appoints swords, dogs, birds, and beasts to execute judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:3 declares that God appoints various agents to slay and destroy, demonstrating His sovereign use of circumstances to fulfill judgment.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 15, what can we learn about God's expectations for separating the precious from the vile in our lives?
options: Believers should distinguish and keep what is precious, becoming God's mouthpiece.
Mixing precious and vile has no spiritual consequence.
All things are equally acceptable to God.
Separating precious from vile is unnecessary.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should distinguish and keep what is precious, becoming God's mouthpiece.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:19 instructs to take the precious from the vile to be as God's mouth, highlighting spiritual discernment and holiness.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 15.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:1, which two biblical figures are said to stand before the LORD yet are unable to change His mind about the people?
options: Moses and Samuel
David and Solomon
Elijah and Elisha
Abraham and Isaac
questions.correctAnswer: Moses and Samuel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:1 states that though Moses and Samuel stood before the LORD, His mind was not toward this people, indicating their intercession was ineffective.

questions.question: What four judgments does the LORD appoint over the people as described in Jeremiah 15:3?
options: The sword, dogs, birds, and beasts
Famine, pestilence, war, and exile
Fire, flood, earthquake, and drought
Sword, captivity, famine, and plague
questions.correctAnswer: The sword, dogs, birds, and beasts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:3 lists four kinds appointed by the LORD: the sword to slay, dogs to tear, fowls of the heaven, and beasts of the earth to devour and destroy.

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:4 connects the forthcoming exile to the actions of which king of Judah?
options: Manasseh, son of Hezekiah
Josiah, son of Amon
Hezekiah, son of Ahaz
Zedekiah, son of Josiah
questions.correctAnswer: Manasseh, son of Hezekiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:4 attributes the cause of the exile to Manasseh, son of Hezekiah, for his deeds in Jerusalem.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:6, why does the LORD say He will stretch out His hand against Jerusalem?
options: Because they have forsaken Him and gone backward
Because they have worshiped foreign gods
Because they have broken the covenant
Because they have oppressed the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have forsaken Him and gone backward
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:6 states the LORD will stretch out His hand because Jerusalem has forsaken Him and gone backward.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:8, what imagery is used to describe the increase of widows?
options: Widows increased above the sand of the seas
Widows multiplied like stars in the sky
Widows gathered like leaves in the wind
Widows scattered like dust in the desert
questions.correctAnswer: Widows increased above the sand of the seas
questions.explanation: The verse uses the simile of widows increasing more than the sand of the seas to emphasize their vast number.

questions.question: Jeremiah laments in 15:10 that he was born a man of what, which causes him strife and contention?
options: Strife and contention
Peace and joy
Wisdom and knowledge
Faith and patience
questions.correctAnswer: Strife and contention
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:10 expresses his sorrow at being a man of strife and contention to the whole earth.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 15:11 promises that the LORD will cause the enemy to treat the remnant well in times of evil and affliction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:11 explicitly states that the LORD will cause the enemy to entreat the remnant well during difficult times.

questions.question: The rhetorical question in Jeremiah 15:12, 'Shall iron break the northern iron and the steel?', illustrates what principle?
options: That one strong power cannot easily overcome another
That iron is stronger than steel
That the northern army is invincible
That weapons will fail in battle
questions.correctAnswer: That one strong power cannot easily overcome another
questions.explanation: This metaphor suggests the difficulty of one strong force defeating another, emphasizing the strength and persistence of enemies.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:13, what will happen to the people's substance and treasures?
options: Given to spoil without price
Hidden and preserved
Restored in abundance
Taken as tribute by a friendly nation
questions.correctAnswer: Given to spoil without price
questions.explanation: The verse declares that all their treasures will be given to spoil without price, as judgment for their sins.

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:14 speaks of passing with enemies into a land unknown. What does this foreshadow historically?
options: The Babylonian exile
The Egyptian captivity
The Assyrian invasion
The Roman occupation
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile
questions.explanation: The passage foreshadows the exile to Babylon, a land unknown to the people, as a consequence of divine wrath.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:16, Jeremiah describes his relationship to God's words using which metaphor?
options: Eating the words, which were joy and rejoicing
A sword in his heart
A fire burning in his bones
A lamp unto his feet
questions.correctAnswer: Eating the words, which were joy and rejoicing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah uses the metaphor of eating God's words as sustenance and joy, highlighting the intimate reception of divine revelation.

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:18 questions the LORD about his suffering. What two metaphors does he use to express his despair?
options: A perpetual pain and a wound that refuses to heal
A broken sword and a shattered shield
A dry well and a withered tree
A lost sheep and a wandering star
questions.correctAnswer: A perpetual pain and a wound that refuses to heal
questions.explanation: These metaphors express Jeremiah's ongoing anguish and sense of abandonment.

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:19 contains a condition for restoration. What is it?
options: If you return, then I will bring you again
If you build altars, then I will forgive you
If you fast, then I will heal you
If you pray, then I will listen
questions.correctAnswer: If you return, then I will bring you again
questions.explanation: The LORD promises restoration contingent upon the people's return to Him.

questions.question: What symbolic role does the LORD assign to Jeremiah in Jeremiah 15:20?
options: A fenced brazen wall
A shepherd to the flock
A trumpet to sound the alarm
A light to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: A fenced brazen wall
questions.explanation: Jeremiah is described as a strong protective barrier whom enemies will fight but not prevail against.

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:21 assures that the LORD will deliver Jeremiah from what kind of hands?
options: The wicked and the terrible
The foreign kings
The false prophets
The priests and elders
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked and the terrible
questions.explanation: The LORD promises to redeem Jeremiah from the hands of the wicked and terrible, emphasizing divine protection.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:1, God states that even if Moses and Samuel stood before Him, His mind would not be toward the people. What does this signify about God's judgment?
options: God's judgment is irrevocable despite intercession
God will change His mind if Moses and Samuel intercede
God is merciful and will forgive all sins
God prefers human intercession over divine justice
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is irrevocable despite intercession
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:1 shows God’s sovereign judgment is fixed despite the presence of great intercessors like Moses and Samuel. This reflects God’s holiness and justice (Isaiah 55:8-9; Romans 3:10-12; Hebrews 10:26-27; Ezekiel 14:14).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:2-3, what four kinds of judgment does the LORD appoint over the people?
options: Death, sword, famine, captivity
Sword, dogs, birds, beasts
Fire, flood, earthquake, pestilence
Judgment, mercy, wrath, peace
questions.correctAnswer: Sword, dogs, birds, beasts
questions.explanation: Verses 15:2-3 describe four kinds of divine agents of judgment: sword to slay, dogs to tear, fowls of heaven, and beasts of the earth to devour. This typifies God's comprehensive judgment (Deuteronomy 28:49-50; Ezekiel 14:15; Revelation 6:8; Psalm 91:13).

questions.question: What is the reason given in Jeremiah 15:4 for God causing the people to be removed into all kingdoms of the earth?
options: Because of Manasseh, son of Hezekiah, for his deeds in Jerusalem
Because of Jeremiah's prayers
Because of the prophets' intercession
Because of the people's righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Because of Manasseh, son of Hezekiah, for his deeds in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:4 attributes exile to the sins of Manasseh, showing how leadership’s sinfulness brings national judgment (2 Kings 21:11-15; 2 Chronicles 33:9-13; Romans 1:18-32; Ezekiel 8:6).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:6, God declares He is weary with repenting regarding the people because they have done what?
options: Gone backward and forsaken Him
Prayed earnestly for forgiveness
Returned fully to His commandments
Built altars to God
questions.correctAnswer: Gone backward and forsaken Him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:6 highlights human rebellion and apostasy as reasons for divine judgment. God’s weariness with repentance indicates His justice and holiness (Psalm 78:38; Hebrews 10:26-27; Isaiah 1:4; Hosea 11:7).

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:9 describes a woman who bore seven children but now languishes and is ashamed. What does this imagery most likely represent?
options: The widespread devastation and loss among the people
A literal woman’s experience
God’s blessing on large families
The joy of motherhood
questions.correctAnswer: The widespread devastation and loss among the people
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Jeremiah 15:9 symbolizes the tragedy and judgment on the nation, showing the depth of suffering and shame (Lamentations 1:2; Isaiah 13:8; Ezekiel 9:6; Matthew 24:19).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah lament about himself in Jeremiah 15:10?
options: That he is a man of strife and contention cursed by all
That he has sinned greatly against God
That he has been wealthy and proud
That he has been ignored by everyone
questions.correctAnswer: That he is a man of strife and contention cursed by all
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:10 expresses the prophet’s personal suffering and rejection despite his blamelessness, illustrating the cost of faithful prophetic ministry (2 Corinthians 12:10; Psalm 69:9; John 15:20; 1 Peter 4:14-16).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:11, what promise does the LORD give concerning Jeremiah's remnant?
options: It shall be well with them, and enemies will treat them well in affliction
They will be completely destroyed
They will have no peace or rest
They will be forgotten by God
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be well with them, and enemies will treat them well in affliction
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:11 promises restoration and protection for the faithful remnant, a key biblical theme (Isaiah 10:20-22; Romans 11:5; Zephaniah 3:12; Revelation 12:17).

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:13 says God will give their substance and treasures to the spoil without price. What doctrine does this illustrate about sin and judgment?
options: Sin leads to loss and divine judgment without redemption
Sin is easily forgiven without consequences
God rewards sinners with wealth
Sin has no real effect on material possessions
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to loss and divine judgment without redemption
questions.explanation: This verse shows that sin brings inevitable judgment and loss, emphasizing God's holiness and justice (Proverbs 1:19; Hosea 8:8; Romans 6:23; Galatians 6:7).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:14, why will God make the people pass with their enemies into a land they know not?
options: Because a fire kindled in God’s anger shall burn upon them
Because they will be honored by foreign kings
Because they requested to travel
Because they were faithful servants
questions.correctAnswer: Because a fire kindled in God’s anger shall burn upon them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:14 links exile to divine wrath, showing God’s righteous judgment on persistent sin (Deuteronomy 28:64; Ezekiel 20:23; Nahum 1:6; Romans 1:18).

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:16 describes how Jeremiah found joy through God's words. What theological truth does this reveal?
options: God’s word brings joy and sustenance even amid suffering
God’s word is irrelevant in times of distress
Joy comes only from worldly success
Prophecy is a burden with no reward
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word brings joy and sustenance even amid suffering
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:16 reveals the sustaining and joyful nature of divine revelation, consistent with Psalm 119:111; Matthew 4:4; John 6:63; Romans 15:4.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 15:18, Jeremiah questions why his pain is perpetual and his wound incurable. What does this express about the human experience of suffering in relation to God?
options: It expresses the struggle with divine silence and perceived abandonment
It shows that suffering is always punishment without hope
It denies the existence of God
It claims God is unjust
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses the struggle with divine silence and perceived abandonment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah’s lament reflects the tension of faith amid suffering, a theme found in Job 3:11; Psalm 22; Habakkuk 1:2; Hebrews 12:11.

questions.question: What condition does God set in Jeremiah 15:19 for restoration and service as His mouthpiece?
options: If Jeremiah returns and separates the precious from the vile
If Jeremiah ceases to prophesy
If Jeremiah flees from the people
If Jeremiah builds a temple
questions.correctAnswer: If Jeremiah returns and separates the precious from the vile
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:19 emphasizes repentance and discernment as prerequisites for restoration and prophetic ministry, aligning with Ezekiel 22:26; 2 Timothy 2:15; Proverbs 3:5-6; Acts 3:19.

questions.question: Jeremiah 15:20 describes God making Jeremiah a "fenced brasen wall". What theological significance does this metaphor convey?
options: God’s protection over His prophet despite opposition
Jeremiah’s isolation from all people
Jeremiah’s weakness and vulnerability
God’s abandonment of Jeremiah
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection over His prophet despite opposition
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Jeremiah 15:20 signifies divine strength and protection for the prophet amid persecution, similar to Isaiah 54:17; 2 Corinthians 12:9; Psalm 18:2; John 10:28.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 15:21, what does God promise to do for Jeremiah in relation to the wicked and the terrible?
options: Deliver and redeem him from their hands
Hand him over to them
Ignore his plight
Make him king over them
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver and redeem him from their hands
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:21 promises divine deliverance and redemption, reflecting God’s saving power (Psalm 34:17; Isaiah 43:1; Romans 8:31; 2 Timothy 4:18).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah ask God to remember and take action upon in Jeremiah 15:15?
options: To remember him, visit him, and avenge him of persecutors
To forget him and leave him alone
To grant him riches and honor
To remove him from the earth immediately
questions.correctAnswer: To remember him, visit him, and avenge him of persecutors
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 15:15 is a plea for divine justice and vindication amid suffering, consistent with Psalm 74:22; Romans 12:19; Revelation 6:10; Hebrews 10:30.
